body: The kernel spec is now stored in the notebook, and when a notebook is loaded, that information is used to start the correct kernel. Which makes nbopen that much more powerful, because you can use it on notebooks in any language.

If you open a notebook written for a kernel you don't have installed, it will try to launch that kernel and fail. This will probably go badly, since we've never had to handle that case before. I suspect that will be a job for a separate PR.

And now we have syntax highlighting that adapts to the language specified in the kernel spec.

Review would be welcome at this point.

Great, will start to review...

Per @Carreau's suggestion, I have now used the JS events API to update the UI when the kernel is changed. I've added a `spec_changed.Kernel` event, which is fired when:
- The user chooses a different kernel from the list
- A notebook is loaded with kernelspec metadata
- A session has started, if the kernel name in the response is different from the kernel name requested. This is to handle the case where the frontend asks for the 'python' kernel, and we only know from the server's reply whether that's Python 3 or 2.

When the event fires:
- The kernel's display name in the top right is updated
- The codemirror mode is set, both for all existing code cells, and the default for any new code cells
- The kernel spec is stored in the notebook metadata

I sent you [a PR](https://github.com/takluyver/ipython/pull/10) that cleanup style a bit :-)

I will try to look at this PR soon. I think we should move this selector
down to the toolbar. A couple of reasons:
- There are already kernel related buttons there (interrupt, restart).
  Conceptually all kernel related controls should be in one location. This
  information should probably include the kernel indicator as well (we talked
  about this when we created the existing kernel indicator).
- Moving forward, we need to keep the top area, as much as possible, for
  content that is common to all pages. This will be especially true as we
  start to integrate the single user notebook server with the multiuser one.
  In that context the top area will likely have site-wide navigational
  elements.
- We have already established the toolbar as the location for the most
  commonly used UI controls as we have a consistent UI for those controls.

Conceptually, I don't think this is so much a kernel control as a document
control. Although technically it works by starting and stopping kernels,
the practical effect is to change the language of the notebook. That feels
like a fundamental operation on the same level, or even higher than,
renaming the notebook.

I also disagree with the notion that the top area should be common to all
pages. About the only thing that's really common is the logo, and pixels
are too valuable to give that space entirely too a logo.

The other issue is that of embedding. If the notebook UI is embedded into
another site (Wakari, Sage Math Cloud, Canopy), it is very possible that
other site will want to remove our top header and replace it with its own.
I don't think any of these sites are doing that currently, but honestly
they should - it takes up way too much vertical space when combined with
their own top headings. Their websites also have other UI elements site
navigation, file renaming, logging out, etc.

When running on Google Drive, I think this (remove our default heading area
and use a different one) is a very likely route for us to achieve UI
convergence = Use our UI from the menubar down, but use a more Googly one
for the top level that has the usual Google site-wide nav elements, sharing
options, etc.

One final conceptual distinction that I think is important is the
difference between the notebook "contents" and notebook "model".
Conceptually, the notebook model is the JSON that gets put onto disk. The
"model" (in our REST-ful API sense) includes the data related to how that
is stored (the filename, last modified, etc.). Right now our UI represents
that distinction clearly. The heading area only affects things like the
filename and modified date that live outside the document JSON.

Despite the fact that Brian raises valid points, I must say that I strongly disagree. 

When designing a UI I do not think you should care about the implementation detail and the embedding use case. UI should be focus in usage.

As you stated, it is commonly known that toolbar is used for frequent action. I know it is exciting to switch language on the fly, but it is likely to be an extremely rare action, majority of the user will not use, and 95% of the rest will use it once when starting each notebook. Half I the remaining power user will change the default.

Thus the kernel selector does not enter the category of commonly use actions. Placing it in the toolbar is _a loss of available space_. Also it is, as you said, a destructive action, so you do not want it to be easily accessible.

I also believe that the "clean separation of abstraction" you - as a developer - see in the UI is invisible to most. I create a notebook with a name and a kernel once, this is a creation step, everything is in the top bar, it's nice. The notebook language would have been store in the filename extension, should we have put the menu in another place ?

As far as embedding, I'm sorry to say that, but it's their job, we already provide simple API to change kernel, it is not as if just commenting one line in main.js would deactivate our kernel selector. 

They have already clearly shown that they can patch these stuff.

I know it is convenient to see things also from dev point of view, but try to forget this POV when speaking UI.

# This design decision:

I agree that our main concern should not be embedding, but usability. But I
don't think we can ignore embedding entirely.

From a usability standpoint I think all of this pivots on one question: is
changing kernel a common action for our users or not?

A) It is common

Then, it should go both in the Kernel menu and the toolbar. This is the
design pattern we are using for all other document/kernel related UI
elements. This choice is also supported by principles of good design:
- It creates visual hierarchy (kernel things grouped together inside
  toolbar between document and menus).
- It puts like things together (kernel things by kernel things, commonly
  used actions in the toolbar, all actions in the menus)
- It is prototypical - users know that web sites use the heading area for
  site-wide content, not document level elements. All of the sites that we
  use and love respect this (github, twitter, google, facebook, apple, etc.)
  and research has shown that prototypically is a strong factor in how users
  experience web sites.

B) Changing kernels is not common

In this case, I think the kernel selection should be done only in the
Kernel menu. We might want to indicate visually what the kernel is
somewhere, but again, for that indicator I would use the above design
principles to pick where it goes: a) next to the kernel indicator or b)
next to the kernel related things in the toolbar or c) somewhere else that
is close to the document in the visual hierarchy.
- Side point: we have also talked about having a small language specific
  icon displayed next to the Jupyter logo (which will replace the large
  IPython Logo we have currently). Do we have enough info in the kernel specs
  to add this feature? I have some common language logos (Python, R, Julia)
  here:

https://github.com/jupyter/design/tree/master/languages

So maybe the first question is: how common will this action be for users
(outside of our demoing it)?

One thing that I feel is important in design decisions is that we start to
develop solid principles we can use to make these decisions. I am starting
to create a wiki page that starts to lay out design principles and some
good references...links soon...

I am more than willing to consider putting the kernel selector in the
heading area if we can establish the underlying design principles that
support putting it there. I personally don't see what those principles are,
but I am being serious about being willing to be convinced. Is the idea
that the kernel choice is really important and should therefore be at a
high level? Is the idea that the heading area, unlike the rest of our UI,
has lots of open space? If available white space is the attraction, what
about starting to use the abundant L/R margins of the notebook document?

Again, this isn't really like the other kernel-related actions we have in the toolbar. From the user's perspective, the important point is not 'I am starting a different kernel', but 'I am changing the language of the notebook'. Even at the implementation level, it has effects besides changing the kernel - it changes syntax highlighting, and puts metadata in the document.

But "changing the language of the notebook" is a kernel level action - the
user completely looses all of the state that the previous kernel had - it
is equivalent to a hard kernel reset. Thinking about it more, because of
this, I think we have to ask the user for confirmation. You don't want to
accidentally change the kernel language and loose a ton of kernel state.
This only emphasizes my point - this is primarily a kernel level action
with smaller document related changes.

I think you're probably right that it should ask for confirmation (perhaps only if some code has already been run in this session?). But I still think that, from a user perspective, you are thinking about the document when you go to change this, not the kernel.

Agreed with thomas, kernel changing is moreover statefull (across restart).
And thus would be the only action in menu that has this effect. 

It is action on document level, which is choosing a language, 
and has IMHO the same status as renaming or choosing other
notebook-level metadata. I don't think many user 
do need to change mid-session the kernel (agreed with warning though).

And a Pyhton, Haskell, R or  Julia  noteook, is inherently Python/Haskel/R, or Julia based, 
regardless of wether kernels runs. The menu does change the language of the **document**
and have the nice side effect of **also** (because we are smart) starting a 
corresponding kernel. Note that with delayed kernel start, this will not even be the case at some point in the future.

I'm very interested in this PR, because it would be useful for me to understand how to extend the thisworks code that I demo'd at SciPy to understand how to expose hashdist and other package manager's ability to build virtual software environments (as represented by their "kernels") to the Notebook.

I think we are getting bogged down in trying to parse the exact proportion of kernel versus document related effects. I am not denying that this action has document related effects and no one is denying that it has kernel related effects. For our users documents and kernels are inextricably linked.

The exact proportion of document/kernel effects doesn't change my case about the design principles governing where overall we should put this UI element. Putting the language selector in the heading is out of existing visual hierarchy, not nearby any other document/kernel related UI elements, not by other commonly used indicators or UI elements and it is in a location that traditionally is reserved for site wide navigation.

Maybe it doesn't make sense to group the other kernel related actions with this selector in the toolbar. I am open to that.

But we also need to get input from @minrk @jdfreder @fperez and others.

Another way that @jdfreder and I iterate on design things is to implement something multiple way and try it out. When working with a designer we would certainly do this. To be honest, right now I would describe my preferences towards the toolbar as thus: I hypothesize that it would better in the toolbar. It would be best for us to try a few things out.
The header area is where we have the notebook title and the save information, which are certainly not site wide, and strike me as conceptually closest to this element.

This [font](http://mfizz.com/oss/font-mfizz) has (some) programming language logo.
If this goes to the toolbar, then I'm leaning toward a super discreet indicator. IMHO toolbar is starting to be crowded.

Right now site-wide information are : `logout` if logged in, and Jupyter Logo.
Github at at top level header 'search this repository' and create new issue/new collaborator for **this** repository. And from a user perspective, I keep hitting the global setting button in header  where I _feel_ the per/repo setting should be. So I really don't see this strong separation you speek about (even if I understand what ou would like to have.

We might want to discuss this with higher bandwidth tomorrow at the online dev meeting.  In the meantime, a couple of things to keep in mind:
- the header and the toolbar can both be toggled off. For that reason, it's important to expose this functionality in the menus, and I'd be strongly in favor of some indicator next to the kernel activity icon as well.  
- I think that changing kernels should be a fairly rare action once a notebook has been created. We shouldn't make it particularly difficult, and we should make it visually very clear always _what_ kernel is running (see my point above), but I don't think people are going to be switching languages back and forth frequently. Other than python2/3, or switching between versions of a given language kernel for experimentation reasons, once you've picked a language for a notebook it kind of makes sense to let it be.
- I think we need to record the default kernel _at notebook creation time_, so that if a notebook is created and saved immediately, it's already a valid notebook. We can work on the UI so that the choice is as easy as possible, e.g. with a button that remembers its default value and has a side-dropdown for quick access to alternatives.  But once created, a notebook should _always_ know how to run code without further user actions (even if we delay kernel starting to first-cell-executed, we should still know what kernel we're supposed to start).
